author: David Hurst For Mail On Sunday
title: Marvellous Marbella... with an extra shot of caffeine
text:
18 shares 1
View
comments
With its café con leches and café bombóns, not to mention its perfection of frothy cappuccinos, Spain is fantástico at coffee – and my wife Debs and I drank far too many cups as we sat in the warming glow of the rising Spanish sun.
The thing is, we needed them to keep up with our two little boys, Daniel and Darley, aged five and four, as they made the most of everything on offer at Camping Cabopino near Marbella.
Included in the price of our motorhome pitch (from £17 a night) was the use of indoor and outdoor pools, a volleyball court, playground, soft play area, trampoline, bouncy castle, rope bridge, five-a-side football pitch, basketball and beach volleyball courts, table tennis, a pétanque terrain and an outdoor fitness circuit.
A couple walking their dog on a sunny day Playa Artola, Cabopino, Andalucia, Spain
The site also has a bar and shop, Indian and Italian restaurants, a vibrant fresh fruit and veg stall, and a bread van that comes round every morning.
Plus there are free lessons in wall-climbing, archery, yoga, Pilates, water polo, aqua aerobics and kayaking at the beach, just a five-minute stroll away.
And what a beauty of a beach, complete with a few chiringuitos (beach bar restaurants) around its crescent bay. Either side is miles of sand and the Artola Dunes to play on.

Behind the bay there’s a small, picturesque marina with luxurious yachts, bars, restaurants and – most interestingly for us – always a school of fish to admire.
We spent three weeks at Camping Cabopino after travelling 15,000 miles around Britain, Morocco and Spain in a Swift Escape 696 motorhome.
Designed with young families like ours in mind with a bunk bed at the back, it has proved ideal for our adventures.
David Hurst's sons, Darley (on the left in blue trousers) and Daniel (on the right in green trousers)
Our odyssey is still continuing – and has taken in dozens of fascinating places, as diverse as Stonehenge, Bath, Bletchley Park, Granada’s Alhambra Palace and the city’s Science Park.
During several months of travels so far we’ve stayed at more than 50 campsites: one phone call before we set off to The Camping & Caravanning Club and we had our Brittany Ferries’ Portsmouth to Santander return ferry trip (from which we spotted dolphins and a minke whale) plus every campsite booked all the way across Spain – right to Camping Cabopino.
Despite being a large campsite with 270 pitches and 60 chalets, it’s family-run and just about the friendliest site we stayed on.
When we were there, our fellow campers were mostly northern European winter-sunners approaching the end of six-month stays.
In the evenings, we would join gatherings by motorhomes and, while our boys played with other children, we watched the setting sun’s orange glow across the bay.
Then a peaceful night’s sleep before waking up to birdsong – and more coffee.
